title: R43557
content: The first section of the report outlines the FY2015 legislative branch appropriations process, including the initial request submission, hearings, markups, and passage of H.R. 4487. It also covers the enactment of continuing appropriations resolutions and the Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act, 2015. The FY2015 U.S. Budget for legislative branch activities was submitted on March 4, 2014, requesting $4.471 billion in new budget authority. Hearings of the legislative branch subcommittees in 2014 were held, with witness statements posted on subcommittee websites. In 2014, witness statements were posted on subcommittee websites. The House subcommittee met on April 4 to mark up the FY2015 bill, providing $3.3 billion. The full House Appropriations Committee held a markup on April 9, with one amendment considered. Representative Moran proposed a housing stipend for Members living 50 miles away, which failed. H.R. 4487 was considered by the House on May 1, with eight amendments, including one by Representative Nugent to prohibit funding through the Member Representational. An amendment offered by Representative Nugent to prohibit funding through the Member Representational Allowance (MRA) of vehicle leasing failed by a vote of 196-221. Representative Speier's amendment to appropriate $500,000 for sexual harassment training for House offices was agreed to by voice vote. Representative Gosar's amendment to reduce funding for the Botanic Garden to FY2014 levels and transfer funds to the spending reduction account was agreed to by a vote of 219-198. Representative Broun's amendment to reduce funding for the Capitol Visitor Center by $243,000 failed by a vote of 207-212. Representative Duffy also offered an amendment. An amendment offered by Representative Hall to prohibit funds from being used to deliver printed copies of the Statement of Disbursements of the House to any Member of the House was agreed to by voice vote. An amendment offered by Representative Wenstrup to prohibit funding for the delivery of printed copies of the House daily calendar to any Member of the House was also agreed to by voice vote. An amendment offered by Representative Holt to appropriate $2.5 million to reinstitute the Office of Technology Assessment, offset from funds in the House Historic Buildings Revitalization Trust Fund, failed by a vote of 164-248. H.R. 4487, as amended, was passed by the House by a vote of 402-14. The Senate Appropriations Committee considered H.R. 4487 on June 19, 2014. The Senate Appropriations Committee considered H.R. 4487 on June 19, 2014, and ordered the bill reported favorably with an amendment. No further action was taken on H.R. 4487 before the start of FY2015 on October 1, 2014. Funding for the legislative branch was provided through continuing appropriations resolutions until the Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act, 2015 was enacted on December 16, 2014. The FY2015 act allocated $4.3 billion for legislative branch operations, a 1.0% increase from the previous year. A funding gap led to a 16-day government shutdown, ending with the enactment of a CR (P.L. 113-46) on October 17, 2013, providing funding until January 15, 2014. Subsequent bills (P.L. 113-73 and P.L. 113-76) allocated $4.259 billion for the legislative branch in FY2014, following FY2013 funding of $4.061 billion from P.L. 113-6. The FY2013 discretionary spending limits were set by the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act, amended by the Budget Control Act of 2011 and the American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2012. OMB calculated additional rescissions of 0.032% of security budget authority and 0.2% of nonsecurity budget authority. Sequestration reductions implemented on March 1 reduced most legislative branch accounts by 5.0%. Division G of the FY2012 Consolidated Appropriations Act provided $4.307 billion for the legislative branch, $236.9 million below the FY2011 enacted level. In FY2011, the legislative branch budget decreased by $125.1 million compared to FY2010. Funding for various agencies like GAO and CBO was provided in different acts. The budget remains below the FY2004 level in constant dollars. The Senate requested a 5.6% increase for FY2015. The Senate requested a $907.2 million budget for FY2015, a 5.6% increase from FY2014. The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended $865.9 million, a 0.8% increase. The FY2015 act provided $864.3 million. The inquiries and investigations account for Senate committees, excluding Appropriations, had a requested amount of $134.0 million. The Senate appropriations committee recommended $133.3 million, a 1.0% increase from FY2014. The Committee on Appropriations account for the Senate Appropriations Committee had a requested amount of $14.94 million, the same as FY2014. The Senate requested $429.7 million for FY2015, with the Senate Appropriations Committee recommending $390.0 million, the same as FY2014. The House requested $1.20 billion for FY2015, but the House-passed level of $1.18 billion remained the same as FY2014. Funding details for House committees are provided in Table 6. Funding for House committees is detailed in Table 6, with subheadings for personnel and nonpersonnel expenses. The House requested $126.3 million for committee employees, $23.7 million for the Committee on Appropriations, and $565.4 million for Members' Representational Allowance for FY2015. The U.S. Capitol Police (USCP) requested $355.7 million for FY2015, an increase of 5.1% from the previous year. The House-passed bill would have provided $348.0 million, while the Senate-reported version would have provided $344.0 million. The USCP is responsible for the security of the Capitol Complex, including various buildings and grounds. Appropriations for the police are contained in two accounts - a salaries account and a general expenses account. The salaries account for Capitol Police includes funds for employee salaries, overtime pay, and government contributions for benefits. The general expenses account covers expenses for vehicles, equipment, training programs, and other administrative support. The Capitol Police requested $291.4 million for salaries in FY2015, with the House-passed bill proposing $286.5 million and the Senate-reported bill recommending $284.6 million. The Capitol Police requested $64.3 million for general expenses, an 8.1% increase from FY2014. The House-passed bill would have provided $61.5 million (+3.4%), while the Senate recommended $499 increase. Another appropriation for Capitol Police buildings and grounds requested $25.6 million, a 32.3% increase from FY2014. The House-passed bill would have provided $19.5 million (+0.7%), and the Senate recommended $20.7 million (+6.8%). The House and Senate subcommittees discussed Capitol Police training requests, radio modernization program, recent incidents involving USCP, overtime use, discrimination complaints, and door closures in the House side of the Capitol. The Office of Compliance, an independent agency, administers the Congressional Accountability Act applying employment and workplace safety laws to Congress. They requested $4.02 million for FY2015, a 3.9% increase from FY2014. The House and Senate subcommittees discussed Capitol Police training requests, radio modernization program, recent incidents involving USCP, overtime use, discrimination complaints, and door closures in the House side of the Capitol. The Office of Compliance requested $4.02 million for FY2015, a 3.9% increase from FY2014. The FY2015 act provided the Senate-reported level of funding for the Office of Compliance. The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) requested $46.1 million for FY2015, with the House-passed bill providing $45.7 million and the Senate-reported bill providing $46.1 million. Discussions at hearings included CBO projections, methodologies, and administrative provisions for FY2015 funds. The Architect of the Capitol is responsible for maintaining and preserving the U.S. Capitol Complex. FY2015 unobligated balances may be available through FY2016. Operations of the Architect are funded through 10 accounts. The Supreme Court buildings and grounds are also under the Architect's responsibility, but their expenses are not included in the legislative branch appropriations bill. The Architect of the Capitol requested $676.6 million for FY2015, an increase of 12.4% from FY2014. The House-passed bill provided $484.9 million, including amendments to reduce funding for the Botanic Garden and offset training costs. The Senate-reported bill would have provided $600.0 million. The FY2015 act ultimately provided $600.2 million (-0.3%). The FY2015 act provided $600.2 million, with administrative provisions related to building façades and educational outreach efforts. It also included language prohibiting funds for bonuses for contractors behind schedule or over budget. Discussions at a House subcommittee hearing included funding for the Capitol Dome rehabilitation project and plans for the renovation of the Cannon House Office Building. The Senate subcommittee discussed the restoration of the Capitol Dome and prioritization of projects. The Library of Congress serves as Congress's library and the national library of the United States, with services including acquisition, maintenance, preservation of a collection of over 158 million items, legal research, and administration of copyright laws. The Congressional Research Service (CRS) provides public policy research, analysis, and legislative assistance for Members of Congress. The Library of Congress requested $593.1 million for FY2015, with the FY2015 act providing $590.9 million. Salaries and expenses were allocated $414.5 million for FY2015. The Library of Congress requested $593.1 million for FY2015, with the FY2015 act providing $590.9 million. Salaries and expenses were allocated $414.5 million for FY2015. The Copyright Office received $18.2 million in FY2014, with a request for $19.5 million for FY2015. The Congressional Research Service received $105.4 million in FY2014, with a request for $108.4 million for FY2015. The Senate-reported bill proposed $107.8 million for the Library, a 2.3% increase from the previous year. The FY2015 act allocated $106.9 million, a 1.5% increase. For the Books for the Blind and Physically Handicapped, the Library requested $50.7 million for FY2015, with the Senate-reported bill proposing $50.2 million. The Architect's budget included funds for Library buildings and grounds, with a total of $62.8 million requested for FY2015. The House-passed bill would have provided $41.7 million, while the Senate-reported bill proposed $47.6 million. The Library requested funds for reimbursable and revolving fund activities, discussed issues in the Copyright Office, management and planning within the Library, plans for the Twitter archive, and book preservation at hearings. GPO requested $128.9 million for FY2015, with the House-passed bill proposing $122.6 million and the Senate-reported bill proposing $122.1 million. The FY2015 act provided $119.99 million. The FY2015 act renamed accounts within the Government Publishing Office, with requested funding for congressional publishing, Public Information Programs, and the Business Operations Revolving Fund. The funding levels varied between the House-passed, Senate-reported, and enacted bills, with some increases requested by GPO. The FY2015 act provided funding for the Government Publishing Office's Business Operations Revolving Fund, with varying amounts requested by GPO and approved in different bills. The Senate-reported bill included a provision to rename the Government Printing Office to the Government Publishing Office, as well as renaming the Public Printer to the Director of the Government Publishing Office. This language was also included in the FY2015 act. The House subcommittee discussed GPO's FY2015 budget request, including printing costs, passports, and the Federal Digital System. GAO requested $525.1 million for FY2015, with the final act providing $522.0 million. The GAO requested administrative provisions for amending reviews and reports, authorizing personnel details, and establishing a Center for Audit Excellence. H.R. 4487 included language for the Center, discussed in House and Senate subcommittee hearings in March 2014. The Open World Leadership Center was established in 1999 to support democratic changes in other countries by inviting their leaders to observe democracy and free enterprise in the United States. It was initially focused on Russia but later expanded to include additional countries. The center is housed in the Library of Congress and receives services from the Library. The Open World Leadership Center, established in 1999, is housed in the Library of Congress and receives services through an inter-agency agreement. In FY2015, Open World requested $8.0 million, with the House-passed bill proposing $3.42 million and the Senate-reported bill proposing $5.7 million. The center was created by Congress in 1988 to encourage public service by congressional staff. The Stennis Center, established in 1988, received $430,000 in FY2013. The House did not provide funding in FY2013 due to lack of detailed budget justification. The House report stated that the John C. Stennis Center, established in 1988 with an initial appropriation of $7.5 million, now has $15 million invested with the Treasury. The Committee has provided zero funding for the Center due to its doubled principal and reduced funding in the Legislative Branch. Any future budget requests must be accompanied by a detailed budget justification. The Stennis Center received funding of $430,000 in FY2011, with recurring provisions in H.R. 4487 and P.L. 113-235. These provisions included limitations on funds, compensation changes, public disclosure of consulting contracts, authorization for LBFMC costs, and freezing pay for Members of Congress in 2015. The FY2015 act enacted a provision freezing pay for Members of Congress. Salaries for Members of Congress are not funded or increased in any appropriations bill. Provisions to prohibit automatic adjustments have been discussed in other bills, and could be included in any bill or introduced separately. The Senate-reported bill also included restrictions on bonus awards to contractors for projects behind schedule or over budget. The FY2015 act included provisions freezing pay for Members of Congress and prohibiting funds for painting portraits of federal government officials.
